posts.name: JONATHAN BERENT
posts.cooked:
When deployed to the robot, this code no longer works:

reader.ready() is false , the streams don’t show available bytes (would normally have the bytes to spell out something like “ArmSubsystem”).

The class loader does have all the classes in it so loader.loadClass("frc.robot.subsystems.ArmSubsystem") does work.

I see no evidence of Exceptions or problems with permissions. One thing that seems different is that the stream appears to be some sort of URL instead of a ByteArrayInputStream . I presume this “url” is to find the resources inside the jar file in ‘home/lvuser’, which I can confirm does contain the “subsystems” folder and classes.

I am kind of new to this and worry about not knowing when or why code will run differently on the RIO.  If this can’t work (e.g., opening “folders” and sub-folders to find ‘Command’ and ‘Subsystem’ classes and their constructors), I would like to understand why. I do not see another way to perform this search.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked: What exactly are you trying to do with the class files inside of the jar?

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
You shouldn’t need to traverse the file system to find constructors to your code unless you’re doing something very outside the box.

Edit: Sorry Ryan, didn’t mean to reply to you and I don’t know how to change it.

posts.name: JONATHAN BERENT
posts.cooked: It is part of a dependency injection scheme that allows the same code-base to run on hardware with different configurations (competition bot, test bot, bot-board, etc.). Configuration info, for example, may determine that certain subsystems should be disabled as well as anything that is dependent on it (like a Command class or another subsystem class). In such a case, they wouldn’t be constructed at all.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: This is probably due to the differences in how projects are ran on sim vs on roborio. On sim, the jar actually isn’t used, and instead just all the classpaths are manually passed to the executable.  We don’t control this behavior, its how the java vscode extension works. Whereas on sim, the jar is used directly. My theory is that jars are not really directory based, so the resource loader doesn’t know what to do with a folder, and just returns resource not found. Whereas when running on sim, it gets an actual folder, so returns something to do with the folder.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
java, list, resources, directory
